page.lettertext:
fol.66r
Belgia. 1591. st
i
R
9 Fe
b
To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r
May it please yo
r
good L. to bee advertised, that where her
Ma
ty
vouchsafed, as yo
r
L. writ unto mee the 27 of the last
to repute mee a fit instrument, to moderate in matters
between
S
r
John Norreis
, and
S
r
Francis Vere
, I have had no
occasion to employ my self in that respect; For I do assure
yo
r
L. S
r
John Norreis hath caried himself w
th
great
discretion, and conversed very friendly aswell w
th
S
r
Francis Vere, as w
th
S
r
Thomas Baskervile
, and all the
other Captaines. The like good endevoure hath bin
also in S
r
Francis, who resolved w
th
him self, before the
arivall of the other, that in respect of her Hig
nes
service,
whatsoev
r
matter of his owne might have moved his
patience, hee would tread it cleane under foote, and advise
every other to take the like course. To saie but a truthe
unto yo
r
L. I do finde him so consyderate and carefull,
to do her Ma
tye
honor in all his ac
co
ns in these countreys,
and his sufficiency is such for the accomplishing of that,
that belongeth to his charge, as her Ma
ty
may expect very
singular service at his hand
. For that I do assure my
self, whatsoever hath bin treated between the
States
&
S
r
John Norreis hee himself by his letter will c
r
tifie
at large, I will not trouble yo
r
L. w
th
that w
ch
is past.
The 5
th
of this moneth hee departed from hence toward
Zeland,
and the next daie after sent
Captaine Crips
w
th
letters to the Captaines in the Province of
Guelder
enjoyning
to bring awaie their troupes, or if the Countrey should
refuse to provide them of meanes, to marche quickly awaie
that then every Captaine should casse his owne companie,
and appoint a Rendevous to
e Souldiers, either at
Flushing
or at the
Briell.
It can not bee gainesaid, but that
her Ma
t
intention for the use of her forces elswhere, doth
apparantly tend aswell to the good of these countreys, as to
the preservation of her owne, yet undoutedly heer, except
wee do observe that course of
ceeding, w
ch
the state of
their affaires & the peoples humo
r
do require, it may growe
fol.66v
Belgia: 1591 Feb
r
very dangerous, to execute her purpose. In this respect S
r
John Norris and I do somewhat differ in judgement. For hee
doth seem to und
r
stand, that her Hig
nes
commandem
t
for the having
of the subject
from hence, is
emptorie, and that w
th
out regard
of the States opposition, or to other perils in apparence, it ought
to bee effected, But I do gath
r
an oth
r
meaning by her
Ma
t
Instructions, that if neth
r
the States will assent to her
demand, nor convenient meanes can be found, to drawe
the Companies from hence, that then S
r
John Norreis should
returne, w
th
out attending further order. First for the States,
I did never see them so perplexed, as they are at this present,
nor I never knew the common people, to take any thing more
to hart, not so much in respect, that her Hig
nes
doth require to
have the use of her subject
, as becaus they are in dout, that
they shall not be returned, and becaus they are thus called
very suddenlie awaie, w
th
out any warning to
e Country, in
a greater nomber then they may spare, and by waie of cassing
the companies, w
ch
they are greatlie afraid, will turne their
estate to some notorious inconvenience. Many good reasons
have bin used to make them alter their conceits, and to
swade
them effectually to a better liking of
e matter, but first they
signifie flatly, that they cannot if they would w
th
out the privity
of the Provinces dismisse any forces, and then againe, since
this l
re
was begun to bee written to yo
r
L. the States have
assembled as they terme it collegialiter, and coming in as
wee sat in
e
Councel of State
, declared w
th
great earnestnes
that for the good of the Countrey, and for the acquital of theyr
owne duties, they had given in charge to their Officers, in
all quarters, where the Englishmen were placed, that they shou
[ld]
not be assisted w
th
an y vittailes, ships, or nedefull
provision
to passe out of their garrisons, and that they had made
a
Protest against S
r
John Norreis proceeding
, w
ch
they w
ould presently
sent unto him by a messenger of purpose. And w
th
all
they
delivered there to mee an authenticall [Insinuation] of the
said
fol.67r
Belgia 1591: Feb
r
Protest, wherof I will enclose the transscript in this letter.
They have also sent the like to S
r
Francis Vere,
S
r
Thomas
Morgan
, and
S
r
Edward Norreis
. I for my part made
t
answeare there unto them, w
ch
I thought to bee fittest for
the appeasing of their passions. I signified that I was in
good hope, that they would better consyder of her Ma
t
request,
since it streched no farther then 3 or 4 monethes, &
would be greatly beneficiall to the generall cause,
And in the meane season they were to conceave, that
her Ma
ty
had no meaning, to have any thing in this
ac
co
n tumultuosly attempted, or to endanger their
estate in any respect, & thus yo
r
L. may
ceave
how the State are affected to S
r
John Norreis
position.
Secondly, for that w
ch
is left to his direction, for
drawing awaie
e companies by cassing or otherwise,
how unpossable it is w
th
out imminent danger to these
Provinces, the ruine of the Companies & p
nt
losse
of those Townes, in w
ch
e English onely are in
garrison. I leave to yo
r
L. to conjecture, for help they
shall have none of
e Countrey people. And when
e
souldiers are discharged and consequently dispersed, and
left to their liberty, it is generallie supposed, that not
half of the nomber will repaire to S
r
John Norreis.
Many no dout, will put them selves in other Companies,
Some will home into
England,
and others to the Enemy
or elswhere, and a very great
te of those in spetiallie
that are tied heer by mariage, will remaine in these
countreys. For as I am informed by divers Captaines,
there are of those that are wived heer above 40 in a
band. Having certified yo
r
L. how
troublesome this matter is growen to
e State, and
how hardly it can bee compassed, w
th
out much
inconvenience, I would most willingly understand, what
her Hig
nes
wilbee pleased to command mee therin.
& so I take my humble leave. From
e Hage
the 9
th
of Feb
r
1590.
postscript
fol.67v
[To my L.]
Treasuro
r
[F
e
]
9. 90
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r
The bearer hereof
Captain Spring
had
e
charge of a Captaine in the
Portugal
voyage
& hath served as Lieutenant
in
is
these Countreys
5 yeares together, if there should bee occasion
to use him in the services toward
in
Fraunce,
I am to witnes to yo
r
L, that hee hath the
report of an honest and any able souldiar.
